instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on, voltage fluctuates.
threads.message:
Hello! I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that does not power on. The amp meter reads 20v but the amps loop from .00a to .50a. I'm not sure of the history of this motherboard but it does look like some rework was done around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: Starts at 13.09V and holds for about 5 seconds then jumps around really fast to  12v 11v 13v 11v 8v then to 13.09v then that cycle repeats
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 0.2V-5.1V Loops 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.4V 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 0v-3.3V Loops 
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>: 19V 
<SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>: 0v-3.2v Loops

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on, voltage fluctuates.
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Did you test the board alone on the desk?
Remove any cable, including battery and trackpad.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on, voltage fluctuates.
threads.message:
Hello, Thankyou!
Yes I had the mother board completed removed from the device with nothing else plugged in.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on, voltage fluctuates.
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground on all big coils.

Try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on, voltage fluctuates.
threads.message: I wanted to report that the motherboard does turn on now and all the jumpy readings I was getting have disappeared for now. I'm not sure why it's working now because all I did so far was test L7030 In diode mode to ground and got 0.466v on both sides.  Before moving on to the next coil I wanted to check  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> again noticed it was at 13.1v and it was steady. I began to check the other rails that were jumpy from my original response and noticed they were steady as well. So with all my rails steady I put the laptop back together turned the machine on and it powered right up!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on, voltage fluctuates.
threads.message: Check if all works good; charging battery, audio, sleep mode, etc...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Not powering on, voltage fluctuates.
threads.message: So far things looking good. Battery Charges, Wifi connects, Audio sounds good,  Sleep mode works. Going to leave it on overnight and check in the morning to make sure everything stays working. We'll see!
